Description: Late Ptolemaic Egyptian sculpture carved from basalt, representing the bust of a bearded man, probably a priest; upper part from a larger statue wearing priestly robes.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Egyptian Museum, Cairo. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Published by Edgar, who dates this to the 1st century BC (Cairo CG27494). Statues and busts of men in basalt or diorite with a back pillar of the mid and late 1st century BC express a similar mood, that of 'gentle sadness and resignation' (Bothmer et al. 1960, nos 131-3 and 136 , dated 80-30 BC, see also earlier 118; Walker and Higgs 2001, nos 138 and 189-90). Similar pieces from Egypt dated to the (end of the) 1st century BC ( MND 2053; AE N 2453; AE E 15486). Bothmer, B. V., de Meulenaere, H. and Müller, H. W. 1960. Egyptian sculpture of the late period, 700 B.C. to A.D. 100. New York: Brooklyn Museum. Walker, S. and Higgs, P. (eds). 2001. Cleopatra of Egypt : from history to myth. London : British Museum.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (CA.19) (Phase 3)
